title: Staying on Task
excerpt: There is always a shiny new toy to catch my eye. Allegory helps me stay focused on the task at hand.
body:
Staying on task has been the hardest thing to do while learning about investing. There is always a shiny new toy to catch my eye, whether it be a new spin-off, merger, news story, or global economic event. I know I cannot learn everything all at once, but I keep trying to — that is part of the reason I made this blog. I want to set clear goals and hold myself accountable. If I know people expect to see results from me, I am sure it will help me stay on task. I almost got distracted today with oil prices and the possibility of the Strait of Hormuz being cut off. If I had more extensive knowledge and decades worth of experience, I may have taken action, but Allegory proved useful. I have a task at hand already. If I go off on a tangent I might learn something, but I cannot devote a whole week to it. I know I am not going to act on the news and I would be too late anyway. I will of course continue to keep up with current events and observe how the market reacts, but I already have a task at hand.

The new microcap list will come out tomorrow as March begins. I remind you, those that stay on the list will keep their percent change from the previous month. As far as the full analyst briefs go, I am still working on the automated system. There have been a few hiccups, so I am working on how to mesh my AI tools with Python scripts that pull data from the SEC's website. The biggest problem I have faced with the AI tools is that they need a hard-stop factual baseline. When pulling from SEC filings, they can mix up different data points if the API defines figures with different names — for instance earnings can be named, "Last Twelve Months Earnings From Sector X" as opposed to "TTM.", or anything in between. Each filer has a different classification that can confuse the system. Right now I am working to automate a hard-stop reference point. Once I can pin that down, I believe I will be able to provide error-free coverages to you.

As for my role in the project, to continue building my fundamental skills I will be picking a company from the new top 10 ranking to do a deep dive on for you all. I will forecast the company and do my own writeup separate from the AI and Python writeups I am working on. This will be published when done or by the end of the month. I do not know how long it will take, as the last writeup I did was mostly a learning process so it took longer. I look forward to continuing to document my progress and interacting as this site grows.

title: Welcome to Alleogry
excerpt: Allegory will document my journey from a bootstrapped dorm room operation to a fully functioning hedge fund.
body:
This is my first full entry here on Allegory, and while I expect the writing to sharpen over time, you have to start somewhere. So here it is.
Allegory will document my journey from a bootstrapped dorm room operation to a fully functioning hedge fund. I currently have roughly $2,100 in my brokerage account. Between my part-time internship and the future revenues of this site, I intend to grow that number and bring you along for the ride.

**The Problem**
I am currently building a set of tools that I will be releasing here shortly. The first one was born out of frustration.
I would set screening parameters on ThinkorSwim, and thousands of tickers would flood the screen  prices, volumes, percent changes, the works. The first time I decided to take a deep dive on one of those names, I got lucky. After hours of reading through tickers, pulling up company websites, earnings releases, and other filings, I landed on a company with a compelling story. It was in the middle of a turnaround, and by the end of my analysis I felt confident it was a good buy.
The problem was the process. I had no way of knowing whether I would get that luck again, or if I would waste two hours scanning tickers and then spend days digging into a single name with nothing to show for it.

**The Solution**
I built something better. I wrote a Python program that scans all 7,000+ microcap stocks listed on the NYSE and NASDAQ. The program evaluates each company on a quantitative basis to determine whether it warrants further analysis. It first applies a set of automatic disqualifiers to clear out the obvious noise, then uses metrics like revenue trends, FCF yield, ROIC, ROE, and P/B ratio (among others) to rank the remaining universe and surface the top 50.

**What You Can Expect**
My goal is straightforward. I will further filter that top 50 and publish the top 10 here on the site as a resource for you. Once my next project is complete, I will begin posting full analyst-level research on the top 5 companies. Both lists will be updated monthly.
Most microcap stocks receive zero coverage from major banks. I am building Allegory to be a resource for retail investors who do their own work and for smaller funds whose position sizing allows them to operate in the microcap space.
That is what I am working on now. I will keep uploading information and stress testing my models. The more work I put in, the more I learn, and the more I can provide for you. I look forward to building this, and I hope it earns your attention.
